Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: IDBR: Enhancing and disseminating miniaturized tracking technology for widespread use on small migratory songbirds
Award.AbstractNarration:
Until recently, knowledge of the migratory movements of small birds was based only on idiosyncratic band returns and inferences from biomarkers and population demographics. Although researchers have been able to track large birds for decades using various electronic devices, traditional long-distance tracking methods, such as satellite telemetry, employ tags that are far too large for the majority of bird species (those weighting 20 grams or less). However, a new tool has emerged that can revolutionize our understanding of bird migration. Solar-geolocation data loggers, or geologgers, are extremely small and simple tracking devices that store light-intensity readings at regular intervals for determining both day length, which indicates latitude, and the time of solar noon, which indicates longitude. Geologgers have recently been deployed on several small bird species and the success of these early studies has sparked considerable interest in these devices among scientists and bird enthusiasts.
Although geologgers are already yielding exciting results, there is a need to improve the instrumentation (both hardware and software), establish guidelines for the use of geologgers, and increase their accessibility to the scientific community. A major goal of this project is to improve upon an existing geologger design to create a device that can be deployed in large numbers on a wide range of species by virtually any research group or institution. A second goal is to generate sophisticated yet accessible analysis tools that incorporate multiple sources of information into a Bayesian framework for generating the best possible estimates of migration tracks. Specifically this project seeks to: 1) reduce the size of geologger hardware; 2) repackage an underused but powerful analysis package (tripEstimation) for processing geologger data; 3) increase the availability of geologgers by offering assembled units, electronic kits, and do-it-yourself instructions; 4) carry out extensive field testing and analyses to evaluate the accuracy of the devices and their effects on bird behavior; and 5) reduce the cost of geologgers by an order of magnitude.

Making geologgers available to large-scale banding operations and researchers with limited funds will promote a tremendous scientific advance that will reverberate across numerous disciplines. As information from multiple tracking efforts is synthesized, researchers will be able to establish connectivity maps linking breeding and wintering areas used by different populations of migratory birds. These activities will enable comprehensive conservation strategies that can identify critical habitats for migratory birds and protect vulnerable species throughout their annual cycles. To help ensure that this sort of data synthesis is possible, the geologger software resulting from this project will be implemented through Movebank.org, an online repository for storing and distributing animal tracking data. Scientists who use Movebank.org will contribute to a resource used by students and researchers worldwide ranging from professional wildlife biologists seeking to advance evolutionary theory to grade-school children working on science fair projects.
Tracking animals with geologgers requires a synthesis of biology, earth science, electrical engineering, and mathematics. As such, geologger studies are excellent material for addressing STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math) learning objectives. Working through The University of Oklahoma K20, a collaborative group of project personnel and schoolteachers will generate lesson plans for K-12 students based on the concept of solar geolocation and the construction of microprocessor-based data loggers. These lesson plans will reach teachers across the US and abroad through the K20alt website, maintained by the K20 Center.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Light level geolocaton is an important innovation for tracking the movements of free-living wildlife. This tracking method entails generation of location data over long time periods (about a year or more) by means of a simple device (called a geolocator) that makes a time-series record of the light environment experienced by an animal from which one can extract estimates of sunrise and sunset times. From this information it is possible to derive an estimate of latitude (based on day length) and longitude (based on the time of solar noon) for each day and night period over the course of the course of the geolocator’s deployment. The simplicity of this tracking method allows for considerable miniaturization of geolocators, and there have been numerous important discoveries made by deploying these tiny devices on bird species that are too small to track with other methods.

            Award 1152356 funded an effort to generate new hardware and software tools to improve the capacity for geolocator tracking by wildlife biologists, with an emphasis on research into small migratory birds (for which other tracking methods are unavailable). With regard to hardware, we developed a small low-cost geolocator design that has now been tested on hundreds of birds representing at least 10 species (see images). This device costs approximately $15 to manufacture, which is an order of magnitude less than the cost of commercially available devices. Moreover the device was, at one point, the smallest tracking device ever deployed, and it currently remains among the smallest tracking devices ever used. Testing of the geolocator designed generated by the project has enabled several important discoveries, including a loop migration in Painted Buntings in Oklahoma (see images), high migratory connectivity among Northern Wheatears in Mongolia, and distinct flyways among Tree Swallows throughout North America.

            The project also supported the development of new analytical tools for geolocator analysis. Thanks to these efforts there have been significant advancements in our ability to infer animal tracks from geolocator data. Among these advancements are new statistical methods that allow for incorporation of animal movement models to improve inferences from light levels as well as simple tools for visualization and editing of geolocator data. Early in the project we established a web-based visualization tool called TAGS (i.e. the Totally Awesome Geolocator Service), that quickly became a go-to tools for editing and examining geolocator data that allowed users to generate a record of their analysis activities and improve the repeatability of their science. The project also supported the development of two sophisticated geolocator analysis packages for the R computing environment. These packages, called “FlightR” and “SGAT” (TAGS backwards) have become the standard for geolocator analyses for migratory birds. To help introduce the packages to the scientific community, project personnel sponsored two workshops at national ornithological meetings to train potential users. The example code and associated materials from these workshops have since been broadly disseminated and have led to the establishment of a forum for discussing and debugging geolocator analyses.

Beyond the primary goals of the project (i.e. improvement of geolocator technology), there have been significant contributions to open source technology development and training of new scientists. The project provided salary support for five graduate students and one post-doc at the University of Oklahoma, and provided travel support for students and post-docs involved in the generation of geolocator analysis packages. The project also provided indirect support (i.e. geolocators, data, and/or analytical assistance) for numerous students and post-docs both within the University of Oklahoma and at other intuitions in the United States and internationally. Meanwhile the project witnessed the advancement of the PI from a post-doc to an associate professor at the University of Oklahoma. Collaborations with industry partners facilitated by the project has led to the establishment of a new biologging initiative at the University of Oklahoma, which will provide a stable source of funding for continued development and dissemination of tracking devices including geolocators, radio transmitters, GPS devices, and RFID technology for animal monitoring.
